For the Construction of these instruments it is the same in sever 
all, and the apparatus is very simple and convenient; They are all 
single Microscopes, consisting each of a very smaller double convex glass,
let into a socket between two silver plates rivetted together, and piercd 
with a small hole: th the object is placed on a silver point or needle,
which by means of screws of the same mettal , provided for that pur 
pose, may be turnd about, raisd or depressd, and brought nearer or put 
further from the glass, as the eye of the observer, the nature of the 
object, and the convenient examination of its several parts may re 
quire.
<u>Mr Lewenhoeck<\u> fixd his objects if they were solid to this silver 
point with glew, and when they were fluid or of such a nature as not 
to be commodiously viewd unless spread upon glass, he first fitted them 
on a little plate of Talk, or excessively thin blown glass, which he 
afterwards glewd to the needle, in the same manner his other objects 
were.
The observation indeed of the Circulation of the blood, and 
some others require a somewhat different Apparatus, and such a one 
he had to which he occasionally fixt these same Microscopes ; but 
as it makes no part of this Cabinet , I shall <s>only <\s> omit giving any 
further account of it, only taking notice it may be seen in a letter 
to the Royal Society of the 12th of January 1689. and printed in 
his <u>Arcana Natura detects. No. 69 <\u>. But I was willing to mention just 
so much, as it may serve to shew the universal use of these Micros 
copes, and as it induces me (amongst other things) to believe, these 
were the kind of Microscopes, generally if not solely usd by this 
Curious Gentleman in all his observations, and to which We are obligd 
for his most surprising discoverys.
